description.text: This door handle is a 3D scanned and a bit remodelled replica of distinctive Pegasus door hook, designed by famous Slovene architect Jože Plečnik. This small part of Slovene national heritage is used to enter the Slovene National and University Library (NUK) in Ljubljana. Object was developed during 3De-Generik experiment/workshop at Ljudmila Lab.

Firstly we took around 100 photos of the original door handle with a Canon camera and sent them to Autodesk 123D Catch, which made the initial 3D model. The object was later fixed and remodelled in Blender and finally adapted to our specific door. To affix it we drilled a small hole in the back round part and put a wood screw in, that keeps it in place. More info on the original source: http://www.slovenia.si/culture/arts/painting-and-architecture/plecniks-ljubljana/

Bring the past to the future with these 3D Printed, LED Stegosaurus Spikes. These 3D Printed spikes are hollowed to diffuse LED lights and printed in Ninjaflex for safe and squishy goodness.

Designed for modeling, or if you want to use filament instead of screws. If you use the 3mm filament for anything but extrusion, you need to contain it. These are snuggly fitting ends and rings to use 3mm in larger holes, or to make it lock outside of a smaller one.
It shouldnâ€™t need any real cleanup. The tapered ring is the best for holding of them all. The tapered versions don't taper very much, but may help self centering. 3mmringtapered12.stl is a plate of 12.
They come up best from a still heated bed, but expect to break 3 pealing them up, and 3 more pressing(hammering) filament into them.
They slide down filament easily, but the ends are always flaired from the cutting, and some force will be required to get them onto it. Glue to make permanent.

title: Pocket-Tactics: Elves of the Shining Host against the Dwarves of the Mountain Holds (First Edition)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: -UPDATE: This (while still playable) is an outdated Pocket-Tactics design. For current sets and rules, go here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:586240 Introducing Pocket-Tactics! A fast-paced, modular strategy board game that all fits in a tiny bag. This is the third set in the series (for the first two, head over here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27257 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28641 . With Elves vs Dwarves, we have an iconic fantasy opposition and this set really stands out from the other two in terms of style and strategy. Of course, either faction from this set can play against any of the factions from the first two, just as every future set will be compatible. We're really excited by the prospect of an ever-expanding universe of factions and locales from all genres (though we're going to thoroughly mine Fantasy first). We'll be updating the progress of the game and provide expanded rules on our blog, so be sure and check us out there as well, and any of you makers should head over to check out our logo contest. illgottengames.blogspot.com/ All models designed in the amazing Tinkercad: tinkercad.com/users/bHIdLANxoGl-arian-croft

Each piece was printed on my Makerbot Replicator at a .10 layer height with 100% infill. I printed them all one piece at a time, though you can feel free to try and print bricks of them. I had trouble doing so and it was probably due to my calibration. So, for the core set as I've designed it, you'll need the following (and I've included the colors you should paint things, though this is only a suggestion): -3 Elven Archers (light green) -2 Elven Realmguard (light green) -2 Elven Way Watchers (light green) -2 Elven Glade Scouts (light green) -1 Elven Wurm Rider (light green) -1 Elven War Mage (light green) -3 Dwarven Warriors (gray) -2 Dwarven Hold Guardians (gray) -2 Stone Throwers (gray) -2 Dwarven Tunnel Scouts (gray) -1 Dwarven Noble (gray) -1 Dwarven Forge Master (gray) -1 Elven Santuary (light green) -1 Dwarven Stronghold (gray) -3 Village Tiles (tan) -3 Cave Tiles (reddish brown) -2 Hill Tiles (light green) -6 Forest Tiles (dark green) -6 Mountain Tiles (gray) You'll also need a grip of six-sided dice (6 for each player) and it helps immensely if half of them are a different color. The rules are in super-beta mode (just finished writing them last night) so expect typos and confusion, but throw me some feedback and I can answer questions/clean up the document as we go. I'd definitely expect some of these abilities to change, but hey, who knows? ;-) -Big props to our tech editor, John Peden ([email protected]) for this new, squeaky clean rules sheet

comments.text: I started to print this incredible set, however had many issues with the PLA on the Rep 2. HOWEVER, now with the new firmware update and software the models look incredible! The detail is perfect, and the overhangs present zero issues. I will post pictures once the full set is complete. Stunning work, the stuff you create is top in its class
comments.author: MrPlastic

comments.text: Hey, that really means a lot to me! Thank you. I'm SO jealous of your Rep 2. Printing these in PLA on my Rep 1 provides the most ideal results, though only one print in five tends to get through to completion. I've actually done a second version of the first set which I'll be posting up later today. I'm probably going to re-design this one in that style as well, though I won't take this version down. Of the three PT sets I did in this style, this was the one of which I was most proud.
comments.author: MrPlastic

comments.text: Awesome stuff, I cant wait to print Version 2 of Pocket Tactics now. I have now tested printing up to 9 pieces at a time of this set with rafts and it worked like a charm. I took a picture of the set and put it up as a thing I made, the detail stuns everyone I show. Now to play a game :)
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: This is some great work, thank you for your efforts. I am currently printing a set but it is not easy. I have a Prusa Mendel which I thought was doing well but the pictures of your prints puts mine to shame. I wasted a day and about 20 prints trying to get something even close, currently using .1 LH, 205deg, no retraction with PLA, 3.5mm nozzle. Still a lot of the detail is lost, and staffs/poles etc. are thin and misshapen. The larger parts are easier. But hopefully I'll have a workable set soon.
comments.author: rickybee

comments.text: Hey, thank you very much. Yeah, these guys can be difficult to print. I do all of my printing on a Makerbot Replicator, so I can't say what it would be like on another brand of printer or how much that would differ. I print one model at a time (when I'm printing in ABS) and a whole set takes close to 8 hours. For me, layer height has been key in achieving the level of detail. I print at a .10 layer height. I've also had more success printing the models at 100% infiill, plus I like the heft it gives them (minor though it may be).
comments.author: rickybee

comments.text: Interestingly, on my setup, I've had better luck printing 2 or more figures at the same time. This gives the current layer time to cool down while the other is being worked on. Anyway, I have nearly finished my first set so I posted a pic. I still have a couple more parts to paint, and I just have a base color so far, but I have to go buy more paint.
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Haha, that's the hard part, right? ;-) Email me if you have any questions.
comments.author: rickybee

comments.text: Have you made your own dice ?
comments.author: LiquidBeef

comments.text: Excellent question. You know, I initially devised a system that had dice with the 3 symbols of the stats on them, though I ended up abandoning those for a few reasons: 1, its way more cost effective to buy standard 6-sided dice in bulk if this ever goes to mass production. 2, I had trouble printing them and (like you said) finding an even weight. 3, the standard d6 system I came up with tested better with my group and I suspect that it makes it more accessible to casual gamers who aren't as steeped in nerdery as am I ;-) All that  being said, I will make another gamen soon that has special dice.
comments.author: LiquidBeef

comments.text: I've often pondered this very problem. What if you print a 100% infill, won't that fix the problem? How badly does the weight problem mess things up?

title: LCD Controller with full size SD card module

description.text:
Updated version in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:533927 but I have also included updated instructions in PDF in source files with schematic diagrams, PCB layout and notes on firmware settings. Although there are many LCD controllers for the RepRap, there are fewer with a memory card that can easily be removed. Most of the SD adaptors are difficult to mount into a box and the micro SD format is uncomfortably small. Although the full size SD card that I have used here is unbuffered, it has proven reliable.
The controls are a rotary encoder with push select and a "back" button
I have put notes on construction in a PDF file in with the "Thing Files"

title: Slug Barrier

description.text: This is a slug barrier designed to keep bugs, mainly slugs, from eating your vegetable. There are 3 parts to this barrier.  The trough, the "Hanover Slug Fence", and the spikes.  The trough is the main barrier because it can be filled with salt or beer.  Beer will attract the slugs and they drown in it.  Salt will keep slugs away due to dessication upon contact.  The "Hanover Slug Fence" keeps slugs from climbing over as well as keeps water out of the trough.  The spikes cut slugs.  In actual product, the spikes would be more dense like mesh wire. I imagine the trough is all that is necessary and the other measures are superfluous.  This is all theory and prototyping has not begun yet.

tags: Slug barrier vegetable garden slug snail

comments.text: You must have some very mean slugs in your part of the world.

comments.text: Over in my tiny garden in Oslo, Norway I can easily pick 50 snails in 15 minutes. If I wait an hour, I can go pick another 50 snails. I'm not kidding. This really is a bad problem where I live...

description.text:
I don't have room to mount a light on my bicycle's handlebars (there's a pack in the way). But my bike has braze on attachment points for low-rider racks on the front forks. I designed this little part to fit on the front fork (it will work on either side). The outside diameter is the same as my handlebars, so the clip that holds my light in place fits perfectly. I suppose you could use it to mount any gadget you don't have room for on your handlebars (Go-Pro anyone?)  
The original design was done in Rhino.

This was a straightforward print on my Makerbot Thing-O-Matic. The front fork on my bicycle has braze-ons with M5 screws to mount a set of low-rider panier racks. The light mount fits tightly against the fork, held in place with the M5 screw.

A case for the Sainsmart 12864 controller, a lot of this is based on Tig29's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:219024 which was used to determine the locations for the various openings, there are two cable exits and i've tried to make them "break out", which may or may not work, since i'm still collecting parts for my printer I'm not in a position to test this out yet :) I've yet to make models for the buttons or the knob but you should be able to use those from Tig29's. All fixings should be m4x10 for the case and captive nuts and m3x10 for the board. Update 09/04/2014, I've added ,models for the knob and button and made some changes to the front piece, notably the stand-offs. Update 13/04/2014, the mount holes for the board and lid have been reduced in size to leave enough material to tap, i've included the captive nuts for mounting from my 2020 mount for this back as well as adding the option of a set in all 4 corners, this is controlled by the "holes" variable being passed when rendering the back panel (0 = none, 1 = for the 2020 mount, 2 = four corners)

This is a dust cap for a DFM12 Festo pneumatic actuator. If installed as seen in the pictures there is allot of dust that accumulates inside the guide rods. Eventually the brass bushings inside go bad. So this is an easy way to address the problem. Update Jan 2015:
I made another dust cap that has a lip going around the actuator to help with splash as well.

They were printed at 0.1mm layer, 2 perimeters and 100% infill. The holes are a bit tight and will need a drill to make the clearance for the M4. But all in all they look great even has the Festo blue and each takes about 2 hours to print.

description.text:
A spool holder created with laser cutting acrylic. Create two of these and using the holes at the bottom, create a vertical structure.  
The slot at the top allows to change filament spools easily.  
This kind of spool holder best suits for a Delta configuration, where the extruder is mounted on one of the sides, and the filament direction is from bottom to top.  
You can also use 4 delrin wheels to create a mobile spool holder.
Created in Openscad.

This is a laser cut shock mount for a SE1000A condenser microphone.It minimises mechanical vibrations coupled into the mic from the stand.

The assembly is more or less self explanatory but I put detailed instructions on my blog.
http://www.jens-kaufmann.net/blog/2010/05/05/diy-lasercut-microphone-shock-mount/
It can be mate from MDF or PMMA (6mm) on any CO2 Laser with 40W or more. I personally used a epilog system. In addition to the laser cut parts you will need:
-a couple of rubber bands (nothing special)
-1 M4 bolt, 15mm thread
-1 M4 washer, and
-1 M4 hex nut
And a M6 bolt to mount it.
Have fun.

description.text:
This is a set of two halves of a clamp to hold the limit switch to the Z axis.  It is small and prints quick, but is a stop gap to my final design
Requires 10mm Z precision rod

PARTS:
1 of each print
2 M3x16 bolts
2 M3 nuts Simply put it around the Z axis precision rod and affix with 2 M3x16 bolts and 2 M3 nuts. I put it at the top of the Z axis, I belive this cost me 14 mm of upward travel. It is designed to trigger on the edge of the printed X carraige end, since on my printer the bushings like to walk around a bit and would ruin the zero setting.
I belive this could be used as a lower limit, I don't think I need to include instructions as to how. this should fix the problem of it costing you some of your upward travel. this is NOT a work in progress, however I am working on a new endstop for myself that will still be mounted up high, but be integrated into the precision rod clamp. I mounted mine high simply to shorten the wire, I like neat.

title: Cube 3D Printer filament spool adapter New and Improved!!!

description.text: This 3D model is based off of the Cube 3D Printer bulk filament spool adapter design but my design has some major improvements. My design is thinner and instead of sitting on the filament guide my design latches into a screw hole on the back. There is also a fillet where the  hole for the pla goes through so that will take some tension off of the printer. It takes up less material, is a better design, and easy to make or modify.

Update: One of the very few flaws in the Robo3D is the rather onerous filament changing interface. I switched to a single knob to see if I would have slippage problems and have had none, so I made a larger version. Now I can easily remove it one-handed and change filament from in front with the use of an added mirror. This saves a lot of time and stress, especially when you have to change mid-print. I also use a weaker spring and a ninjaflex grommet so it doesn't go shooting off across the room anymore.

This is a simple upgrade, but wow, what a difference it makes in ease and convenience. It employs 2 replacement bolts (M4 Hex head, 50mm) which I was able to source at a True Value store. It is a bit snug, but I found that I could tap it in without cracking the plastic. Scale up a tiny bit if you want it to be easily removable.

remixed_from.title: K8200/3Drag PCB Router depth control slider

description.text:
PCB milling assembly which features a vent channel allowing efficient cleaning of waste from cutting. This is a three part solution which is the mount, baseplate and slider. It is an improved version of this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:288823 Source in openSCAD so you can alter dimensions. Demonstration video here:
http://youtu.be/HnI0M1igDow

HOW TO PRINT
Base and mounting plate print without support.
The slider must be printed with the slider surface on a smooth surface (eg. ikea mirror) so it must be printed with support. I was having printer problems with my prints so the top side finish is bad. It should print ok with 0.3mm layers, 20% honeycomb infill. PARTS LIST
2 M5x20mm Bolt
6 M5 washers
4 M5 Nuts
1 M625 Bolt
1 M6 washer
1* M6 Locknut
25mm Hose
Gaffer tape for attaching hose to vacuum cleaner (should print something better) USING SCAD SOURCE
The source is split across three modules. Rod, mounting and slider. The K8200_rod.scad file should go in the library directory "../K8200_rod.scad". It is a modification of the original K8200_rod avaialble here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247948 WARNING
If you use a plastic hose with a ribbed texture then it will make the nastiest screeching sound as the air flows through it. Wear some kind of ear defenders. I got a little tinnitus from running it for 10 seconds.

The .stl files with "_nf" in the name are binary files and are much more compact than the ASCII files previously provided. Cymon: thank you for the recommendation. I will be deleting the ASCII files after I convert them to binary. chain_8_large_120828c_nf.stl is 43 link chain binary file (2.42 Mb) chain_8_short_120829a.zip is a 7 link chain (shown in photo) mail_8_large_120828a_nf.stl is a 56 link chain mail binary (3.15 Mb) mail_8_large_120828a_connected_nf.stl is a 56 link chain mail binary. The first and last rows are connected by 1 mm thick layer to keep the chain mail from tangling. (3.15 Mb) mail_8_small_120827c.zip is a 10 link chain mail sample (shown in photo)
mail_8_large_120828a_connected_nf.stl is a 10 link chain mail sample. The first and last rows are connected by 1 mm thick layer to keep the chain mail from tangling.

mail_8_120829b.skp - sketchup file for all chain mail versions One picture shows the "short" and "small" test versions of chain and chain mail. A photo of the 43 link chain is shown as printed.

title: Stereoscopic iPod nano mount

description.text:
You can print in 3D, how about recording video in 3D!? This simple yet elegant mount accepts two fifth gen iPod nanos enabling the creator to record their daily webvlogs in glorious stereoscopic 3D video. Here is a video of its practical application!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6uC4OnRAmbo
I do not have a makerbot to print out one of these puppies but the video shows you all you need to understand the implications of this. I will use the $#!7 out of a makerbot, I am about to be a father (due date, MAY 5!!!) baby toys, baby things, all things baby, i want to print them in 3D on a makerbot. Also on my 3rd waste veg oil powered bus conversion tour, with lovely wife and baby too, many useful and fun things will need to be made, rapidly. makezine.com/go/makerbot Love,
Ray Roy

Print it out, pop in your ipods, start recording right eye and left eye video! The design of this \"thing\" is simple, you are using two video recording devices (in my case, two iPod nanos, 5th gen) to emulate the optical disparity between you right and left eyes, giving your brain the illusion of real depth. Because one of the iPods has to cover up the controls of the other one to reach the \"sweet spot\", you should hit record on your iPods first, and then pop them into this stereoscopic holster. To achieve true stereoscopic viewing of your video, sync up and composite the right/left footage in whatever high end video editing software you have lying around. Seriously theres so many ways to skin a cat, and even more ways to watch a 3D video recording of a cat. YouTube has a 3D video upload feature and tutorials, you simply composite your video footage to be side by side, and YouTube does all of the various formatting for you (anaglyph, cross eyed, side by side, etc...) http://googlesystem.blogspot.com/2009/07/youtube-3d.html enjoy. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DE1FsYnFGK4

tags: stereoscopic video stereo 3D ipod nano 5g camera mount

comments.text: The time difference between two 30ths of a second is negligible for all "normal" paced motion.  If you were recording a rocket blasting off or a hockey game or something at a very high shutter speed on REAL cameras, you might notice something fishy, but on an iPod (not a phone) all you need to do is hit both record buttons at the same time and sync it up in post.  If you have the skills needed to make "magic eye" patterns work for you, you can view test footage of stereoscopic video shot on two ipod nanos at the link in the description.  you have to cross your eyes and focus while they are crossed.... if you arent used to this, you will probably get a headache, but you wont need any additional hardware  8-)

title: 22 x 22 mm Glass Cover Slip Holder

description.text:
While doing research as an undergraduate, several of my labmates had to constantly clean 22 x 22 mm glass cover slips in a special solution for microscopy experiments.  They could only wash these cover slips ~5 at a time with some repurposed equipment.  Realizing how frustrating this must be, I designed a modular cover slip holder that can be used to hold 20 cover slips at once, or many more when stacked in a beaker.
Dimensions are 55 mm in diameter, 30.7 mm tall.

Just load the holder with glass cover slips, place in beaker, and fill beaker with cleaning solution. This design is meant to be manufactured via 3D printing. Cover slips to be cleaned in aqueous solutions can use this model if printed in ABS or PLA plastic. Cover slips to be cleaned in organic solvents should print this model using Selective Laser Sintering with nylon (PA2200). This model is provided for free, but if you'd like to purchase this and support a first-year grad student, please visit: http://stark060.storenvy.com/products/550492-22-x-22-mm-glass-cover-slip-holder or https://www.etsy.com/listing/108152563/22-x-22-mm-glass-cover-slip-holder
Thanks!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

This thing replaces the clip that keeps a folded umbrella stroller folded. Ours was lost in luggage land.
The STL is for 10-11mm diameter frame rods, which seems pretty standard for North American umbrella strollers. Both sides snap tightly onto the rods, but I added a channel for a zip tie to prevent history repeating itself.
I banged it out in Sketchup, complete with manifold/watertightness errors; the STL is fixed in Netfabb Basic.

Print it! It worked for me after only the most cursory calibration of the axes.
One ring has a channel for a small zip tie: snap it onto a rod (e.g. the "back" rod) and optionally secure it with said small zip tie. 
The other ring has a bump: this side snaps on and off a nearby rod (e.g. the "seat" rod).

comments.text: Thank you!

comments.text: Calibration of 3D printers. Due to it's shape it is well suited to test how good a FDM-type 3D printer is at stopping the flow of plastic between each of the four pillars. This is normally done using "retraction" where the plastic filament is pulled back some mm into the tube while the print head moves.

I've been answering many of the same questions when I show off my printer.  So, I created a quick FAQ. The LibreOffice file creates a tri-fold brochure answering a number of the common questions.  I've made this generic with the expectation that you will personalize it for your own use.
Let me know if any of the text can be improved.

• Download the most recent *.odt file.
  • Open it in Libre Office (or Open Office)
  • Change the text to match your name, domain, etc. Change out the images if desired. (I like my pictures, but I have no pretense that they are the best).
  • Print in Duplex mode (if you have a duplex printer. If not, print a bunch of one page only, then re-insert the printed pages with the right orientation and print the second page.
  • Fold the printed pages in three.
  • Distribute to anyone who has questions about 3D Printing.
    • Changes:
    2012-08-30: [The Rev3 file] Fixed a typo error reported by Dan ("soluble", not "soluable"). Changed wording for PLA plastic to read "starch/sugar based". description.text: Accidently the part 104 was missing for my LC+ printrbot. So I designed a new one. In that case, I redesigned it so the stepper motor fits better and the z-end switch is more centered. Part 104 is now 5mm thick h104b).

Instead of zip tying better use M2 screws to fix the part with M2 washers and M2 bolts as shown in the picture. My M2 were a little bit too large, instead of 28mm you can use shorter ones.
I provided also the 6mm original thickness as stl file (h104), in case you have different tolerances. For any inbetween you can add washers. Its very tricky to get the switch at the rioght position, so its not colliding whith the hole when activated.

ok, this is a last ditch effort to get my bowden cable to stay in place. it looks like it is holding so far. try it yourself and see if it works for you. it uses a bunch of small nails to bite into plastic tubing be it teflon or polypropylene. included is a parametric file that you can change for example if you want to use screws.

use the stl file, or make your own with the scad file. it aint perfect, but you can figure the things to change easily. i make the nail length smaller than needed to ensure i have room to spike the nail in real good. it looks evil when the spikes are way out there! use with wades block, and this mount for ultimaker
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14822 1) print out object
2) clean up 1/4 inch hole and size it with drill, make it snug with the tubing that goes inside it. 3) place tubing inside it, then place a drill bit end, or something that fills the void that is strong and likely will not allow a nail thru inside the tubing 4) hammer tap in the nails into the tiny holes in the side. you want enough force that the tubing is pierced. 5) repeat for the rest of the nails. 6) pull out part that was inside the tubing. 7) now with an allen wrench wiggle around the inside of the tubing. you want the points of the nail to stop at just the point where it breaks thru the inside diameter of the tubing 8) place this part in a wades extruder, then feed your feedstock thru. happier days now wait you. 9) tell people about this ugly thing!

description.text:
WARNING.
Socket is incomplete. You have to finish it your self depending on where it would get attached to.
Search for similar models to get the idea of what you want. Dock for DROIDX. Fits both standard and Extended battery pack.
Openings for Power button and charger. Volume controls are also accessible.

For easier ball joint rotation, print at 0.1 height or less.
I printed at 0.3 with 15% infill (15% solid) and it came out OK.
Hammer the ball into socket prior to attaching it to the frame with a screw.
To help it stay together, use some glue for plastic or acetone between the frame and the ball piece. When you screwing the screw in and hear the frame or the ball crack, heat it up with hair dryer to make it softer.
Or heat up the screw with lighter to make it go in eazier. If ball gets loose inside the socket, use tightening straps around the socket. Groove is there just for that purpose.

A 3-leg spider bracket to hold a 5mm (T1-3/4 pkg.) LED inside a 2-inch (52 mm) ID pipe. I wanted to hold the LED accurately in the center and this bracket does that. I used 2-inch plastic conduit (Schedule 40 PVC pipe) which Home Depot sells in 10-foot lengths.   
The parametric OpenSCAD file allows choice of any ID, OD, and thickness if you have some other diameter pipe or smaller/bigger center items.  
When printed from MakerWare 2.4.1.24 on Replicator Dual with standard profile, each of the 3 arms (intended to be solid) actually have a thin center gap, which you may see in the photo. Anyway it works as intended.

I just printed on the Makerbot Replicator Dual (110 C build platform) with the standard resolution, without using a raft. It came out quite nicely. Pretty simple design so will likely print without much trouble.

description.text: Description: 1:100000 (1cm = 1km) scale tiles of most of the Tararua Ranges, near Wellington in New Zealand. Each tile covers a 10km-square area. Z-axis scale has not been 'enhanced'. Thing Files: ZIP of 14 tiles (STL), plus corresponding Topo50 map excerpts. File naming convention: name corresponds to Easting/Northing of lower, left corner of the tile (numbers to 4 sig fig), e.g. tile "1780_5450" represents the 10km square whose lower, left corner has coordinates E1780000/N5450000 (NZTM2000). You do not need to download the non-zipped STL Thing File - it was included just so that Thingiverse had a sample to render. The data I used to build my map tiles was created by the University of Otago, National School of Surveying and was sourced from koordinates.com under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 license. Topo50 map excerpts were sourced from the LINZ Data Service under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 license. I used the ASC version of the DEM file, and cut it into 10km-square tiles with some code I wrote. Rendering to STL was done with Accutrans3d (winner of the most appalling UI ever created). I'd also like to credit @Shapespeare for his/her tutorial at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1 - I didn't end up using much of his/her process or tools, but it was an invaluable walk-through of what needed to get done.
